close_symbols: struct MHD_Daemon (complete definition: all fields used here, especially worker_pool_size, worker_pool, master, listen_fd, itc, and worker_pool element type)
daemon->worker_pool (field) and its element type (what &daemon->worker_pool[i] points to)
MHD_itc_activate_ (function) — called inside the loop body
MHD_ITC_IS_VALID_ (macro or inline) — used in the loop body to decide control flow
MHD_stop_daemon (function) — recursive call in the second loop (to see side effects on parent daemon fields)
mhd_assert (macro/function) — used heavily; may expand to code with side effects in some builds
MHD_PANIC (macro/function) — called on error paths inside the loop body
explanation:
To decide whether the two for-loops in MHD_stop_daemon are MISRA ‘‘well‑formed’’ you must check: (a) that the loop counter (i) is initialized and only modified by the third clause, and (b) that the second clause (i < daemon->worker_pool_size) does not use an object that is modified by the loop body or by any function called from the body. Therefore you must know the exact definitions and side effects of the symbols below:

- struct MHD_Daemon: needed to understand types, whether worker_pool_size is the same object as or aliases any object modified in the loop body, and what the worker_pool elements actually are (so you can tell whether operations on worker_pool[i] can affect worker_pool_size).

- daemon->worker_pool_size: this is the loop bound (second clause). You must determine if it can be modified by assignments in the loop body or by any called function; its type also matters for overflow/behaviour analysis.

- daemon->worker_pool and its element type: writes to daemon->worker_pool[i].shutdown and calls using &daemon->worker_pool[i] could modify parent fields if elements alias parent state; you must confirm they do not modify worker_pool_size or the loop counter.

- MHD_itc_activate_: this function is invoked inside the loop body. Its implementation must be inspected to ensure it does not modify daemon->worker_pool_size or the loop counter (or other objects used in the second/third clauses) — if it had such side effects, the loop would violate the rule.

- MHD_ITC_IS_VALID_: this macro/inline is evaluated in the loop body; its expansion may have side effects (or reference other objects) so you must confirm it does not change worker_pool_size or the loop counter.

- MHD_stop_daemon (recursive call): the second loop calls MHD_stop_daemon(&daemon->worker_pool[i]). You must inspect that recursive call’s behavior (on worker daemons) to ensure it does not modify the parent daemon->worker_pool_size or the loop counter variable in the calling frame.

- mhd_assert: assertions can be implemented as macros that evaluate expressions or even mutate state in non‑standard builds. You must confirm the assertion implementation used here has no persistent side effects that would affect the for‑clause objects.

- MHD_PANIC: if invoked it may abort or perform other actions; verify whether it could modify daemon->worker_pool_size or other objects of the for-clause (important when reasoning about side effects and reachability).

Collectively, these symbols let an analyzer determine whether the second clause (daemon->worker_pool_size) or any other object used in loop clauses is modified by the loop body or by any called function, and thus whether the loops satisfy the MISRA requirement about well‑formed for statements.
